children.tweet: RT @GordonBrianR: I think Lewis is completely backwards on this issue; the market would be *rigged* if price discovery was thwarted, not wh…
@GordonBrianR ...but still is rigged if some class of traders can systematically extract rents from others, purely based on transaction info
@GordonBrianR Thanks for your thoughts, but I strongly disagree. Possible to have market that appears efficient in price discovery...1/2
@GordonBrianR Studies of markets show that "price discovery" v info is only meaningful *on average* over a long timeframe--days, weeks, mos
@GordonBrianR If you haven't seen it already, look at research by @nanexllc. Much detailed evidence on #HFT http://t.co/E1wiFAjhMQ
@MrMeritology first, thanks for the feedback. There are lot of issues to untangle here I think. Basically, my thinking was inspired by +
@MrMeritology the BATS CEO's reply to the issue, he argues that HFT traders have enabled brokers to substitute algorithmic capital for +
@MrMeritology financial capital in the provision of liquidity to the market. At least on the margin. from this perspective, HFTs comprise +
@MrMeritology part of the brokerage architecture. What is important is the role they play in the market, not the organizational structure.
@MrMeritology after decimalization drove down profits in brokerage, the risk was that less capital would be allocated to market making.
@MrMeritology by driving down spreads, IBs and market makers had less incentive to provide liquidity; exacerbating info inefficiencies.
@MrMeritology into this environment, the HFTs come in and provide additional liquidity while also speeding info transmission about what
@MrMeritology large block traders are doing in the mkt (the scenario outlined by the 60 minutes piece last night). For this, they earn a fee
@MrMeritology that is some sense, from a functional perspective, not too far off from the bid ask spread that mkt makers traditionally earn.
@MrMeritology when a large block trader makes a move in the mkt, that implicitly does contain information, I would argue.
@MrMeritology the HFT qua broker thus earns a fee for the provision of liquidity and for the transmission of 'notice' of this move to the +
@MrMeritology rest of the market. What I would argue is that role provides economic value as seen as part of the brokerage infrastructure.
@MrMeritology the fact that HFT might be independent organizations doesn't really matter much from this perspective. no more so than the +
@GordonBrianR OK. I'd call it "functional" rather than "structural" but I understand your distinction.
@MrMeritology architectural would be specific algos, institutions, regs, players, etc., while structural is role as sub for mkt maker.
@GordonBrianR I don't understand the distinction in this case between "architectural" and "structural"
@MrMeritology that is definitely problematic and needs to be addressed. But it's an architectural issue, not necessarily a structural one.
@GordonBrianR True, but with todays volume X velocity, liquidity evaporation results in frequent "flash crashes" in individual stocks.
@MrMeritology true, but was always the case that qtd price was indicative of the market makers inventory. If you exceed that, it was higher.
@GordonBrianR No, it doesn't signal intentions of traders who hold large inventories overnight & longer. HFTs rule millisecond relm.
@MrMeritology the evaporation of liquidity in these situation is itself a signal about the intentions of large players in the market.
@GordonBrianR Hayek's analysis operates on time scale of hours, days, weeks, and months. Not milliseconds.
@MrMeritology to extent that moves reflect idiosyncratic info/judgement, it is useful for it to be incorporated into the price, per Hayek.
@GordonBrianR From what I've read, Game Theory and multi-agent social behavior dominates in millisecond realm.
@GordonBrianR "liquidity" concept isn't meaningful if it can evaporate in sub-second realm. Analogy: quantum mechanics vs classical physics
@GordonBrianR "liquidity" like is a classical physics state, eg. position & momentum. In quantum physics they are coupled probabilities
@MrMeritology that is an interesting analogy. I guess it would hold if HFTs drained liquidity from the market, though, no?
@GordonBrianR Are you familiar with the term "Denial of Service" attack? No such attack is possible in exchange market of Smith/Hayak/Walras
RT @MrMeritology: @GordonBrianR There is *no* econ justifucation for "quote spam" http://t.co/i5m4h2X4YZ http://t.co/Q43TikTSqB http://t.co…
@GordonBrianR There is *no* econ justifucation for "quote spam" http://t.co/i5m4h2X4YZ http://t.co/Q43TikTSqB http://t.co/yPRmT2LO6E
RT @MrMeritology: @GordonBrianR You'll find that this pattern of quotes vs trades is the norm in HFT, not the exception. http://t.co/i5m4h2…
@GordonBrianR Economic theory of comp. markets doesn't allow for any trader identifying&exploiting any other specific trader.
@GordonBrianR One explanation: HFT algos are predators on other HFTs. http://t.co/yPRmT2LO6E
@MrMeritology really interesting. How is the discrepancy between quotes and trades normally accounted for?
@GordonBrianR yup. good interview. saw it earlier.
@MrMeritology a very good interview. It certainly added to the 60 Minutes piece.
@GordonBrianR And also on Daily Show, and on Fresh Air (NPR) and everywhere else. Charlie Rose interview is the best, as usual.
@MrMeritology algos may, in fact, be predicting non-HFT informational trades in ways that more quickly transmit info to the mkt, consistent+
@GordonBrianR https://t.co/L222npMEWj http://t.co/YRj4LOfMsN
@MrMeritology Michael Lewis is on Charlie Rose for the full hour right now.
@GordonBrianR HFT insiders don't talk. Everyone employed has very strict non-disclosure terms in contracts. Spokespeople talk liquidity.
@MrMeritology that is, how do HFT insiders explain it?
@MrMeritology the Hirschey paper looks very interesting, from a quick skim of the intro, he seems to be saying that anticipatory trading +
@MrMeritology with the case I was outlining. That is, that HFTs provide liquidity + aid price discovery to the market at a cost to non-HFT.
@MrMeritology what's interesting is idea that as spreads compress, deviations from classic 'pure liquidity' trader returns may be adaptive +
@MrMeritology by enabling good returns for provision of capital for liquidity trading in a regime of compressed spreads, ie decimalization.
@MrMeritology if this is the case, then maybe it's the Gaussian model of the pure liquidity trader that is ill-specified in the current mkt?
@GordonBrianR Sub-second domain of financial markets are the land of Game Theory, not equilibrating economic markets.
@MrMeritology and how do critics explain what's going on?
@GordonBrianR You'll find that this pattern of quotes vs trades is the norm in HFT, not the exception. http://t.co/i5m4h2X4YZ
@MrMeritology huh...that is definitely interesting. How is it explained? Algo gone wild/design flaw vs malicious/weapon?
@GordonBrianR Evidence of Denial of Service attack in sub-second realm by HFT algo. http://t.co/h8OdTDwS4n 5.8m quotes, 137 trades in KEY
@MrMeritology right. As you noted earlier, there are signals indicative of pure liquidity providers vs others.
@MrMeritology the big question, then, is whether or not the population of HFTs is homogenous.
@MrMeritology that is an entirely different story. Almost always out matched by the firms they are supposed to oversee.
@GordonBrianR It appears that regulators (SEC) are either complicit or hopelessly outmatched and understaffed. They are AWOL, certainly.
@GordonBrianR If HFTs are providing functional liquidity, then faster access to exchanges should be irrelevant.
@GordonBrianR Why do HFTs pay multi-millions for a few milliseconds of speed advantage? B/c they don't make $ on liquidity.
@MrMeritology can regulators discriminate between functional liquidity providers and predatory HFTs.
@GordonBrianR That would be fine if that's what happened the sub-second scale. But HFT environment is far different world.
@MrMeritology but the same holds for any bid ask spread. To buy, you pay more than spot price, to sell you get less. Broker makes money.
@GordonBrianR Yes. But to answer that question requires instantaneous measures of liquidity. Most research uses methods from 2000 & before
@MrMeritology is the liquidity in the market now less than the liquidity pre-HFT? Are costs higher? I think that's the first order question.
@GordonBrianR They are "transaction fees", but not for reliable liquidity. For any given transaction ≈ extortion, b/c HFT controls spreads.
@MrMeritology if not, then the costs are just transaction fees paid for liquidity, paid to HFT counterparts rather than broker.
@MrMeritology my suggestion, in this case, is that we have seen an unbundling of brokerage 'functionality'; an architectural transformation.
@GordonBrianR No, I didn't see anything about traders being harmed by the fact that their *intent* was signaled.
@GordonBrianR What was signaled was the *fact* of their buy/sell order, for the sole benefit of the HFT who could front-run them.
@GordonBrianR The rest of the market players, who may have bids or asks in the market or may be thinking of trading, have zero info. benefit
@MrMeritology but the story in the 60 minutes episodes was, essentially, that the trader was harmed by their intent being signaled.
@MrMeritology and in case like that, my point was that *these* costs are offset by other shareholders gains. Up or down, the info content +
@GordonBrianR HFT in no way facilitates the signal to the rest of the market.
@MrMeritology implicit in the trade is transmitted to the rest of the market.
@GordonBrianR I believe there is no transmission of meaningful/relevant economic information in sub-second realm where HFT operates.
@MrMeritology true. But under HFT regime, arguably the transmission is faster. Whether that's in fact beneficial is another question.
@GordonBrianR Large block "signal" would be there without HFT.
@GordonBrianR I believe there's a statistical signature of pure liquidity provider: Gaussian distribution of returns w/ mean≈bid-ask spread
@MrMeritology and that's an interesting question from a regulatory perspective. Some HFTs may be predatory while others beneficial.
@GordonBrianR Right. Then we can't evaluate HFT purely on effect on price changes or effect on bid-ask spreads.
@GordonBrianR Same logic justifies laws against insider trading.
@GordonBrianR front-running and bid-ask manipulation w/ quote spam are mechanisms for "systemic advantage"
@GordonBrianR If one class of traders (HFT) has systematic advantage on another (everyone else)--takes $$ from them--then it's rigged market
@MrMeritology If defined by affect on valuation, then the question implies that the answer is no. If no change in price, no harm
@GordonBrianR The good news for HFT analysis is that there is abundant data & analysis thanks to folks like @nanexllc http://t.co/E1wiFAjhMQ
@MrMeritology undoubtedly not a satisfactory answer. In part, because a priori, no way to tell whether or not any trade will affect price.
@GordonBrianR Do corporate "insiders" who trade on private information harm regular investors if they aren't large enough to move the price?
@MrMeritology but that is different than saying that HFTs have rigged the market and harm 'regular' investors.
@GordonBrianR I'd guess that HFT returns are NOT Gaussian, but are heavily skewed right, with very large number of transactions.
@MrMeritology right. Price move could be up or down. What is 'gained' by the market is signal that a large block trade is being executed.
@GordonBrianR Collapse in liquidity lasting milliseconds doesn't favor higher stock prices. No difference between up and down "crashes".
@MrMeritology while the transactor is adversely affected by those moves, other shareholders benefit from the higher valuation, for example.
@MrMeritology what's interesting is idea that other shareholders actually benefit from the price action that signals large block moves.
@MrMeritology the loses/costs seen by the transactor co-occurs with info gains across the rest of the shareholders implicit in the trade.
@MrMeritology the gain is implicit in the price action, I would argue. It's a Smithean/Hayekean gain.
@GordonBrianR I seriously question whether the market as a whole or other shareholders have any informational gain as side effect of HFT.
@MrMeritology informational gains that are realized by the price action, up or down, that results from the large block trade.
@GordonBrianR What does "liquidity" mean if it can disappear in milliseconds? It's there except when you need it most.
@MrMeritology @nanexllc I will definitely take a look.
@GordonBrianR Yes, that is the public justification of #HFT by firms & exchanges. But analysis by @nanexllc and econo-physic show otherwise
@MrMeritology no. Rather that some aspects of HFT can be seen as a substitute for traditional brokerage. A subset of HFT strategies/roles.
@MrMeritology and that those roles can be seen as economically valuable even if other roles/strategies are more 'parasitic'.
@GordonBrianR are you saying that HFT is nothing more than liquidity providers that make money on bid-ask spread equiv of old market mkrs?

@MrMeritology wow. great article. thanks.
@MrMeritology that definitely covers a lot of the territory that I was thinking about.

@GordonBrianR Beyond 2010 system-wide flash crash, there were 18K crash events in individual stocks btwn 2006-2011. http://t.co/7tvG1m47r1
@MrMeritology completely agree that issues like the flash crash illustrate structural issues that need to be resolved/regulated.
@GordonBrianR There's a diff w/ old market maker system: flash crashes. See: http://t.co/7tvG1m47r1
@MrMeritology fact that traditional brokerage was provided by a large number of independent firms, who all earned fees from this role.
@GordonBrianR Information that drives #HFT has nothing to do w/ economic price discovery. Economists would call them called "noise traders"
@GordonBrianR millisecond level changes in price happen 2 to 4 orders of magnitude faster than changes in idiosyncratic info of traders
@GordonBrianR Plus construct of "price discovery" fails at microlevel b/c changes in price are uncorrelated w/ instantaneous changes in info

tweet: I think Lewis is completely backwards on this issue; the market would be *rigged* if price discovery was thwarted, not when it works.
